sampleData.text: --tapes.
And it made it more difficult.
And we are rolling.
So we were just discussingthe interviewer methodology.
And I-- if you're willing,and you don't have to--
to comment, yousaid that you used
to do five to seventestimonies in one day, which
to me is mind-boggling.
I can't imagine doing that.
I can't imaginethe mental stamina
and the physicalstamina it takes.
And you said you swam tokind of relieve yourself.
And you talked a little bitabout protective amnesia.
But at that point, youwere so immersed in it.
And also, five daysa week, working
as a psychiatrist, as-- as aninterviewer and as a survivor,
yourself, how did thatimpact the process for you?
And do you think that,in general, survivors
should be interviewers?
Should be interviewed?
Should be interviewers?
If I take myself asa model, then, yes.
Of course, their own experienceis alive and awakened.
I think that part--
exans-- an example of thatis my interview of my mother,
that she spoke of experiencesthat I was part of.
And they were the same.
Or they weredifferent, sometimes.
And there was, uh, momentsin which I pointed out
the difference andmoments I kept silent,
because she needed it totell it the way she told it.
Uh, I think the survivorherself knows whether she
could be an interviewer or not.
You know, if it take-- theremay be people for whom this is
so, uh, upsetting, so--
uh, such-- causes suchan emotional storm,
that they shouldn'tbe interviewer.
But they will know it.
And they will know it,at least till they try.
And they know what-- theyfind out that they do it.
It's-- I have alifelong training,
how to involve myself andcome back to m-- to the orig--
my original self, so.
And be completelythere, yet return.
Does it take a toll?
Yes.
Will I need to swim after this?
Yes.
And I probably will go swimming.
Uh.
Is there any alternativeway to do it?
And I say this withqualifications-- no.
You have to be all theway there and to live it
and to struggle withit and to feel it.
And sometimes, it's terrifyingin order to make it--
make it come into being.
You can stop faking.
No faking here.
Um.
So if survivors were--are able to live a life,
they're also able to have an--
to do an interview and to,uh, be in-- into themselves
and into the experiencethey are sharing,
they are h-- they arehearing, and the-- the impact
that the one has on the other.
Um.
Do, uh, particularsituations stir me up more?
Absolutely, uh,particularly when
there's terrorinvolved, when, uh,
German uniforms are present.
And I'm not talkingempty uniform,
I'm talking with, uh,the soldiers inside.
And I remember my ownmoments of terror in that.
And, uh, maybe that's how I can.
The-- the personinterviewed feels
better understoodand better, um,
touched if they sensed thatthey elicit something in me.
So, uh, do I pay a price for it?
Yes, I pay a price for it.
It's not-- I have tobring myself back to--
What is terriblyimportant is that you--
interviewer feelsloved, that he's not--
not alone.
And, uh, I was veryfortunate in that way.
I felt loved as a child andalso throughout my life.
Um.
I think, you know, I'm freeassociating, and that's OK.
I think that here is howI married [? Johanna, ?]
who was able to not only crossan ocean but cross a religion,
cross an experience, andbecame an observant Jew.
And it was a way ofloving and being with me.
And, uh, that wasenormously empowering.
Uh.
So it's, uh, theinterviewed's relationship
but stemming from a--
a relatedness of theinterviewer, who can offer it.
Um.
And I think it continuesto be a relationship
after the interview is over.
And I found that, whenI re-interviewed people,
that we were-- there was a verystrong connection between us,
although we hadn'tspoken for decades.
Even, it was embarrassing thatI'd forgotten who they were.
And, uh--
But not the reverse?
Pardon?
But not the reverse?
No.
But not the reverse.
No.
And, uh, I-- in some case,I'd forgotten [INAUDIBLE] part
of their story.
But in others, I rememberedtheir story, very vividly.
And there arepsychological factors
why there is more forgettingor less forgetting.
So when you didthese re-interviews,
you didn't watchthe first testimony
before you went in todo the re-interview?
No.
I didn't want to do that, no.
I wanted to rely onwhat I remembered.
And that was for anotherproject, not for us.
That was for anotherproject for--
uh, funded by the Slave Labor--
Right, right.
But when we did there-interviews here,
we did watch thefirst testimonies.
I don't know ifyou remember that.
I remember, vaguely, yes.
Right.
Yeah.
And, um, you know, thatwas part of our protocol--
Yeah, yeah.
--in doing those re-interviews.
Um.
Going back to the-- the wholedevelopment of this methodology
and the way you think about itand the influence you've had,
um, and contrastingit with others, it--
I think it's, um--
I don't want to usethe word "risky,"
but it takes a lotmore confidence--
Mhm.
--to do what you doand to do what we do,
than it does to go inwith a set of questions.
Sure.
And I'm wondering-- and--
and it's risky to do what wedo, because we expose ourselves
to the potential ofhearing terrible--
I-- I-- there isn't words.
There aren't words to describesome of the experiences
that we've heard.
But with a questionnaire,you control that.
So it's much less risky.
Mhm.
Now, do you think that, inspite of that questionnaire,
people can share those memories?
I think thequestionnaire is a buffer
and probablyreduces the sharing.
Except that there is ainternal pressure to tell
and a yearning to be heard.
So that's why, now, interviews,simply making this available.
It wa-- the child was born.
It came out withsome help, sometimes.
So I think that, in spiteof the questionnaire,
people will speak andsay what is pressuring,
because it's a relief.
And there's this--this yearning.
And whether-- atleast, they can--
for them, there canbe an imaginary, uh,
listener behindthat piece of paper,
that page with the questions.
Um, it's bo-- also likely thatthe interviewer will interfere.
And it's enough that you showthat you don't want to hear,
and then it's all--
there's no story--there's no testimony.
So, again, it-- it'sa wide spectrum.
In some situations, yes, the--something will come through.
In others, it willbe chopped off.
Do you think that there's anydifference between those early
testimonies, that were takenin the '70s and '80s, only--
I'm saying "only"--
30-something to40-something years
after the experience,and the later ones,
that you did re-interviews of--of people who are now 60 and 70
years from this experience?
I-- I think thetime li-- time is--
uh, I don't think there'sa difference between '70s
and '80s and the--the later ones.
There could be a differencebetween '45, '47,
and the later ones.
And I've a little--uh, uh-- studied them,
both their interviews.
Mhm.
And they have much morea quality of immediacy
and of an appeal.
There's a message ofthis-- the "shtetl brennt,"
to tell that maybesome help will come in.
It's not yet over.
Uh, even, still rescue andchange the course of history.
That's a quality of theimmediate interview.
My daughters were takenaway, sent to Auschwitz.
But are they dead?
The question mark.
So those earlyinterviews are a--
have a quality of a cry forhelp and for intervention.
Whereas the laterone, it's clear
that the daughter is dead.
And how does one deal with amemory and the last moments?
And, uh, there'swork that has been
done, in the-- in theinterim, by the survivor.
But I do not know that there'sa difference between the 1970s,
'80s, and later on.
Yes, I-- what I can sayabout the interviews,
that when Ire-interviewed people,
Leon's interview, thefirst time, is one hour.
The second time istwo and a half hours.
Well, that was because youonly had one hour of tape.
We had 20-minutes tape then.
Tape.
But, you-- you know, itwas very limited, by the--
It was limited.
And so but who is the cause?
I think, it's also ourways-- way of interview,
of knowing how to interview.
And it's a com-- verymore differentiated story,
that he was not onlya-- the thief of bread
but the bread bringer.
He worked in a bakery andbrought her, uh, bread, each--
and he used to extract thebread through the window.
And then there were grates,so it was two sticks.
That this cut upthe bread next time.
So he enourished his family, notonly took bread to his family,
nourished.
This was a very different.
So the first memory was like acover memory, a screen memory--
Mhm.
--that didn't tellthe full memory.
But is it Leon who has in--
uh, integrated more,knows more with age,
or is it our interviewing thatwas different 25 years later?
That's very interesting to me,because, when we were doing
our re-interview project,which was quite a bit earlier--
it was in the early tomid-'90s-- and we asked Leon.
He said no.
He what?
He said?
He said no.
He didn't want tobe interviewed?
No.
He wouldn't be re-interviewed.
Interesting.
You know, we asked allfour of those original.
And two said yes,and two said no.
And Leon said no.
So, you know, I'm just wonderingabout the passage of time.
Yes.
Again, you are raisingquestions that I
think should be studied in amethodological, rigorous way.
And unfortunately, I don'tsee that study happening.
Or maybe having the testimonies,it will happen one day.
Well--
You asked me one thingthat I-- that I regretted,
that there's notmuch more sub-facets
studied of the testimonies.
And there is--
Well, you need another lifetime.
I need another lifetime, yes.
For many things, I would--
I would accept itwith gratitude.
But I know what I have.
Now, is there anything else,that I haven't asked, that you
think it's important to say?
I think we have covered.
Thank you for coming in today.
Thank you.
